Identification_Area.title: Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter Cosmic Ray Telescope for the Effects of Radiation

Changed inst LIDs from u:n:p:c:i:instID.scID to u:n:p:c:i:scID.instID And per "Guide toPDS4 Context Products" v1.7, changed all lidvid_reference to lid_reference

External_Reference.reference_text: Spence, H.E., A.W. Case, M.J. Golightly, T. Heine, B.A. Larsen, J.B. Blake, P. Caranza, W.R. Crain, J. George, M. Lalic, A. Lin, M.D. Looper, J.E. Mazur, D. Salvaggio, J.C. Kasper, T.J. Stubbs, M. Doucette, P.Ford, R. Foster, R. Goeke, D. Gordon, B. Klatt, J. O'Conner, M. Smith, T. Onsager, C. Zeitlin, L.W. Townsend, Y. Charara (2010), CRaTER: The Cosmic Ray Telescope for the Effects of Radiation Experiment on the Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter Mission, Space Sci. Rev., 150, 243-284, DOI: 10.1007/s11214-009-9584-8.

Instrument.name: Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter Cosmic Ray Telescope for the Effects of Radiation
Instrument.description: The Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter (LRO) Cosmic Ray Telescope for the Effects of Radiation (CRaTER) is designed to directly measure the linear energy transfer (LET) spectra caused by space radiation penetrating shielding material. CRaTER will fill knowledge gaps regarding radiation effects, provide fundamental progress in knowledge of the Moon's radiation environment, and provide specific path-finding benefits for future planned human exploration. The investigation hardware consists of a single, integrated sensor and electronics box with simple electronic and mechanical interfaces to the LRO spacecraft. The CRaTER sensor front-end design is based on standard stacked-detector, cosmic ray telescope systems that have been flown for decades, using detectors developed for other NASA flight programs. The analog electronics design is virtually identical to the robust and flight-proven design of the NASA/POLAR Imaging Proton Spectrometer that has been operating flawlessly on orbit since 1996. The CRaTER instrument has only two modes: powered up and powered down.
